div1.p: No. 65. Consular. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, March 9, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill Assistant Secretary of State Washington.
Subject. Anthony D. Williams Esq., a Liberian citizen, nominated for Vice Consul General, for Liberia.
Synopsis. Hon. Anthony D. Williams of Monrovia Liberia; ex Secretary of War and Navy, Liberian Government, is nominated as Vice Consul General for Liberia.
Consular Bureau. MEMORANDUM.
April 9, 1901

Mr. Cridler: Mr. Smith's original suggestion was that the office of V.C.G. need not be filled. We told him that it had better be filled and said we should be pleased to appoint Mr. Spurgeon to the position.

As Mr. Spurgeon is an American and Sec. of Legation it seems to me that his appointment as Vice Consul General would be better than that of a foreigner, even as good a man as Col. Williams appears to be.
R.S.C.
No. 65. Consular. Legation of the United States. Monrovia Liberia; March 9, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to say, that in reply to your No. 37, Consular, of Jan. 31, 1901 (which reached me March 7, 1901), relative to the demise of Vice Consul General, Beverly Y. Payne, late of this Consulate General, with the further instruction, that it is the desire of the Department that a Vice Consul General be appointed; and that the Department would be pleased to Commission the Secretary of the Legation. Mr. Spurgeon, as Vice

Vice Consul General, should it please me to make the nomination; I have to say, that I seriously regret, that having previously solisited the service, experience, ability and association of Col. Anthony D. Williams, a Liberian of this city; ex-chief clerk in the State Department, ex-Secretary of War and Navy, Liberian Government, as my choice for Vice Consul General, should it prove to be the pleasure of the Department, at Washington, to appoint one, I cannot conscioutiously nominate the Secretary of the Legation. Mr. Spurgeon, for said Vice Consul Generalship; but do instead, hereof, nominate Anthony D. Williams, a very respected Liberian citizen of this city, for said position.

Col. Anthony D. Williams, A. M., ho was unanimously elected lay dele- te to the General Conference is the on of the late Rev. A. D. Williams and Mary A. Lewis, sister of the late Gener- John N. Lewis. He was born at Mt. cott, Cape Palmas, December 20, 1842. t that time his father was presiding der on the Cape Palmas district. His other died over forty years ago in Monrovia, leaving him and his younger brother to the care of his father and widowed sister, Mary A. Ferguson. His ather, Rev. A. D. Williams died at Robertsport, Grand Cape Mount, while ischarging the duties there as superin- endent under the administration of the ate President S. A. Benson about forty years ago. Mr. Williams was then bout 17 years of age.

He attended the Monrovia Seminary, Now the College of West Africa, under the tutorship of the late Rev. Dr. J. W. Horne, Principal. After Mr. Horne's return to the United States, young Williams entered Alexander High School then taught by the Rev. E. W. Blyden, (now Dr. Blyden.) He remained there till the opening of the Liberia College in 1860. He left college before graduating to take the position of chief clerk in the

Treasury Department under the late John H. Chavas, Sec'y of the Treasury. He was subsequently transferred to the State Department and served as clerk under Hon. H. R. W. Johnson, then Secretary of State. A few years afterwards he was elected chief clerk of the House of Representatives during the Speakership of W. S. Anderson, and served in that capacity five years. Mr. Williams has been a member of the National Legislature ten years, serving one term in the House of Representatives and two in the Senate. He was three times a candidate for the Presidency of the Republic. He has served also as Secretary of War and navy, and is at present Principal of the Preparatory Department of Liberia College.

Mr. Williams has been Colonell of the First Regiment for twelve years, and has served in six military campaigns: He has been a member of the Masonic Lodge for thirty-three years, and is now Past Deputy Grand Master of the Grand Lodge of the Republic, also a Past Noble Father of Russell Memorial Lodge No. 4451 G. U. O. of O. F.

Mr. Williams comes from good Methodist stock, his father having been one of the founders of the Methodist Episcopal Church in this country. He is therefore, a born Methodist and is thouroughly devoted to Methodist interests. He is now a member of the official board of the Monrovia Methodist Episcopal church under the Rev. J. C. Sherrill.

His wife, Mrs. Maria Williams who has been his companion for thirty years, is an active worker in the Sabbath school. She is the founder and director of the harity Hall for the poor. She is also president of the modest little Christ Hospital of Monrovia. Her interest in, and devotion to the poor and needy have won for her the name of "Modern Dorcas of Monrovia."
Liberia College conferred the degree
18 THE NEW AFRICA.
of A. M. upon Mr. Williams eight or ten years ago. He gave two years of faithful service as Principal of Monrovia Seminary (now the College of West Africa) under Bishop Taylor's administration.

All are agreed that no better selection could have been made than the one that has wisely been made in unanimously electing Col. Williams to represent the laity of our Church in the General Conference. He has had large experience in both curch and state, and will make a good representative. We give him as to our ministerial delegate our hearty endorsement and congratulation, and wish for him the highest success and best results in the interest of our work in Liberia.
The Re-opening of Liberia College.

An event of much importance in Liberian occurrences was the formal opening of the state institution in Monrovia. The new president of Liberia College, Hon. and Rev. G. W. Gibson, D. D., was inducted into office on Wednesday, Feb. 21, by public cereonies in the Providence baptist Church, and in the presence of official representatives of both the Republic and foreign nations.

President W. D. Coleman adminstered to the new president the oath of office and made a short address in which he congratulated Dr. Gibson upon his appointment and upon the greater opportunities for usefulness, which will be afforded him in his new position. He then in appropriate words placed under his charge the charter, seal and keys of the college.
In the course of his remarks, President Coleman referred to the new departure, which has been taken by the Trustees of the College under the sanction of the Legislature as follows:--

"The Legislature at its recent session passed Act to which I have had the satisfaction of fixing my official signature, which has giv to the state a more immediate and direct in est in the conduct and condition of Liberia ledge than has ever before attached to them. refer to the Act making certain appropriatio from the public revenue for the support of institution."

Legation of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, West Coast, Africa. March 8, 1901.
The Barnes Undertaking Company, No. 293 South Lincoln Street, Chicago, Ill.

Sirs, I have the honor to say that your letters of December 13, and 27, 1900, to the State Department, Washington, relative to the remains, expenses etc. of the late Beverly Y. Payne, of Liberia, late Vice Consul General of the United States to Liberia, reached me March 7, 1901. I have just to-day, March 8, 1901, had an interview with the legal representatives of the deceased. They say they notified Mrs. Amanda Smith, North Harvey, 11, by cable, through their New York agents, Messrs. Yates and Porterfield, Williams St., New York City, not later than Nov. 8, 1900, to have the remains interred in America. Mr. E. W. McGill, Collegtor of Customs for this port; and brother-in-law to the late Beverly G. Prague, says he wrote you sometime since (probably trhough Mrs. Amanda Smith) advising that the remains be interred and a statement of expenses etc. be forwarded to him for settlement. He complains that he has not yet received a
reply. He now asks that you write him direct, through this Legation, giving a full statement of expenses, etc. and proper arrangements will be made to meet same.
Hoping an early reply etc., I have the honor to be, Yours, etc., Owen L. W. Smith, U.S. Consul-General.
